By the way, I see in the PR that you're assuming the space is an inner product space, but this shouldn't be relevant (i.e., this works for any additive Haar measure on a finite-dimensional real vector space). For a space of the form R×E\mathbb{R} \times ER×E (and derivative along the first vector), this follows from integration by parts along the first variable and Fubini. For a general space (and a general direction v), you can find a linear equivalence with a space of the above form which moreover sendsv to the first coordinate vector, and then argue using that linear equivalences commute with integrals.

(To find a linear equivalence sending v to the first coordinate vector, you can first find an arbitrary linear equivalence L by equality of dimension, and then use docs#SeparatingDual.exists_continuousLinearEquiv_apply_eq to find another linear equivalence sending L v to the first coordinate vector. All these are continuous by finite-dimensionality).
Orthogonal to this, but do you think you could have a look at #10268? I'd like to construct the Fourier transform on Schwartz functions, and this is the first baby step.
